Tomato___Late_blight.description: Late blight is a severe fungal disease that affects tomato and potato plants, often causing rapid plant decline.
symptoms: Dark, irregular spots on stems and fruit
Wilting and yellowing of affected leaves
treatment: Apply fungicides such as copper sulfate or chlorothalonil
Remove and destroy affected plant material
Ensure proper spacing to improve air circulation

Tomato___Leaf_Mold.description: Leaf mold is a fungal disease that primarily affects the foliage of tomatoes, leading to reduced photosynthesis and growth.
symptoms: Yellowish spots on upper sides of leaves
Fuzzy, olive-green fungal growth on the undersides of leaves
treatment: Use fungicides like sulfur or neem oil
Prune infected leaves and remove debris
Increase airflow and avoid overhead watering
prevention: Remove fallen leaves and plant debris
Use drip irrigation to avoid wetting foliage

Tomato___Septoria_leaf_spot.description: Septoria leaf spot is a fungal infection that causes spots on tomato leaves, leading to premature defoliation.
symptoms: Small, dark spots with gray centers on lower leaves
Leaves turning yellow and dropping prematurely
treatment: Apply fungicides like chlorothalonil or copper-based products
Remove infected leaves immediately
Improve plant spacing for better air circulation

Tomato___Spider_mites Two-spotted_spider.description: Spider mites are tiny pests that cause significant damage to tomato plants by feeding on plant cells, leading to stippling and leaf damage.
symptoms: Yellow speckling or stippling on leaves
Presence of fine webbing on the underside of leaves
treatment: Use miticides like insecticidal soap or neem oil
Spray plants with a strong jet of water to dislodge mites
Encourage natural predators like ladybugs
prevention: Regularly inspect plants for early signs of mites
Keep plants well-watered to reduce stress

Tomato___Target_Spot.description: Target spot is a fungal disease that causes dark, concentric-ring spots on tomato leaves, reducing plant vigor.
symptoms: Small, round lesions with dark concentric rings
treatment: Apply fungicides like copper-based or mancozeb products
Remove affected leaves to reduce spread
Improve air circulation by spacing plants appropriately
prevention: Rotate crops to reduce disease buildup

Tomato___Tomato_Yellow_Leaf_Curl_Virus.description: Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus (TYLCV) is a viral disease that causes yellowing, curling, and stunting in tomatoes.
treatment: There is no cure for TYLCV, but remove and destroy infected plants
Control whiteflies, which transmit the virus, with insecticides
Practice proper sanitation and remove plant debris
prevention: Avoid planting tomatoes in areas with a history of TYLCV

Tomato___Tomato_mosaic_virus.description: Tomato Mosaic Virus (ToMV) is a viral disease that causes mottled yellow and green leaves, reducing tomato yield and quality.
symptoms: Mottled yellow and green pattern on leaves
treatment: There is no cure for ToMV, but remove and destroy infected plants
Use resistant tomato varieties
Disinfect tools and equipment to prevent spread
prevention: Use virus-free seeds and resistant varieties
Control aphid populations, which can spread the virus
Practice crop rotation and remove infected plants

Tomato___healthy.description: Healthy tomato plants exhibit vigorous growth and produce strong, green leaves, with no visible signs of disease or pests.
treatment: Maintain regular watering and fertilization schedules
Monitor for pests and diseases regularly
Prune dead or diseased branches promptly
prevention: Ensure good soil health and proper drainage
Provide ample space for growth and airflow
